sentences: Hanka Paldum (Serbo-Croatian Cyrillic: Ханка Палдум; born 28 April 1956) is a Bosnian sevdalinka singer and founder of the record label Sarajevo Disk.
section: N/A

sentences: She is regarded as one of the best female sevdah performers of the 20th century and is popular in her home country of Bosnia as well as in the rest of the former Yugoslavia.
section: N/A

section: == Biography ==
== Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: 1956–71: Early life and family =
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===
== Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: Hanka Paldum was born in the eastern Bosnian town of Čajniče to Muslim Bosniak parents Mujo and Pemba.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: Paldum has an older brother Mustafa and two sisters, Raza and Rasema.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: Her father was a logger and her mother wove carpets to provide additional financial assistance for the family, as her fathers salary was not enough to carry a family of seven.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: Hanka, the oldest female child, began helping her mother with housework at the age of five.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: When Paldum was seven years of age, her parents moved the family from Čajniče to the Vratnik neighbourhood within the Sarajevo municipality of Stari Grad.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: Paldum started singing in the first grade, as part of the choir in her primary school.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: She would continue singing throughout her childhood and recalled in an interview: "We went by train to my aunt's home, my mother's sister in Rudo.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: There were a lot of tunnels and when the train entered a tunnel, I would sing, and when it come out of the tunnel I stopped, because I was shy.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: The other passengers would ask who was singing that beautifully, and I just looked out the window as if it did not apply to me.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: But inside, my heart was leaping with joy.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: "At the age of twelve, Hanka's brother Mustafa, a member of the Bratstvo (Brotherhood) cultural association, encouraged her to sneak out through her bedroom window and sing at the association events, promising to "cover" for her.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: She would sing for 15 to 20 minutes and run back home.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: The director of the House of Culture named Marijan Ravlić, asked her parents to allow her to sing at some local events.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: Her father allowed it, but with only with the presence of her older brother, Mustafa, who was no less strict than their father.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: Then Hanka began to sing in amateur contests, which she often won, with the award being chocolate with rice or ten tickets for the cinema.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: She shared the chocolates, while tickets for the theater remained unused because of her father's strictness.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: After three years of struggle, Hanka proved to her parents her passion for music and said she wanted to enroll in a music school.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: Her father told her she must enroll in a school that would lead to a secure career with which she could find a job that would earn her money.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: Around that time, Hanka's father, Mujo became gravely ill and soon died of his illness.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: Her younger brother Mustafa died in 2007 of lung cancer, aged 49.
section: == Biography == | === 1956–71: Early life and family ===

sentences: 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: Paldum passed an audition at Radio Sarajevo and began voice lessons.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: After two years of hard work, she made her first archival recordings for Radio Sarajevo.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: They were sevdalinka songs, a traditional Bosniak genre of folk music.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: Her first recording was her version of an old sevdalinka song called "Moj behare" (My Blossom).
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: She continued recording and recorded over a hundred sevdalinkas for radio archives.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: Paldum recorded and released her first extended play (EP) in 1973, at the age of seventeen, when producer and composer Mijat Božović offered her his partnership in recording two singles "Ljubav žene" (The Love of a Woman) and "Burmu ću tvoju nositi" (I Will Wear Your Wedding Ring) alongside the big folk orchestra Radio-TV Sarajevo.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: She recorded five more EP's in two years before releasing her debut studio album, I Loved Unfaithful Eyes on 13 February 1974
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: Also in 1975, Hanka won top prize at the festival of amateur singers called "Pjevamo danu mladosti" (Sing for the Youth Day), with the song "Pokraj puta rodila jabuka" (On the Roadside, a Tree Bore an Apple), written by Mijat Božović.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: Her prize was a chance to produce a single for the record label Sarajevo Diskoton.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: This song was not a big hit at the time, but with time it gained moderate success.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: She continued her partnership with Mijat Božović, who believed in her talent and that she would become a big folk star.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: He wrote a song for her called "Voljela sam oči zelene" (I Loved Green Eyes) which in a few months became a big hit; for a long time the song was Hanka's signature song, and is still a hit among people of the former Yugoslavia.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: There is also a version in Slovenian.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: After success with "Voljela sam oči zelene" she performed as a debutante at the Ilidža Festival with the song "Ja te pjesmom zovem" (I Call You with My Song).
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: The song was disqualified because one of the judges at the time, Milan Radić, who was a reporter, thought that the song was not worthy enough to enter the competitive part of the program.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: However, after the songwriter Julio Marić insisted the song be placed in the competition, Hanka indeed went on to compete.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: This song became a big hit and it still played and has been covered my multiple other artists.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: Hanka met her first husband Muradif Brkić, a student of literature at the University of Sarajevo, while she was in high school.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: After three or four months of friendship, they began dating.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: They married soon after he graduated from the university in the late 1970s.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: Shortly thereafter, he went to the mandatory service in the Yugoslav People's Army, and Hanka started her first big Yugoslavian tour with Meho Puzić.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: She and her first husband had two children: a daughter Minela and a son named Mirzad.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: She was pronounced clinically dead when giving birth to their son, but survived.
section: == Biography == | === 1972–78: Radio Sarajevo, first recordings, and marriage ===

sentences: Hanka started singing at all of the elite places in Sarajevo alongside Omer Pobrić, a gifted and popular accordion player, and by doing so gained vocal and performing experience.

sentences: Then, with Hanka and Braco Đirlo, founded a record company called "Sarajevo Disk".

sentences: After hearing Milić's song "Volio sam volio" (I Loved, I Loved), Muradif recommended that Hanka record that song.

sentences: At first Hanka was hesitant and even Milić wasn't too thrilled about the idea: "I was a bit skeptical at first, but when I heard how Hanka sang that song; when I felt the power and temperament of her voice, I knew we were going to take over Yugoslavia", Milić said.

sentences: She recorded her version in a 'home studio' owned by innovative producer and ethno-pop composer Nikola Borota – Radovan.

sentences: Their meeting was instrumental to her career and climb to the stardom.

sentences: Hanka's interpretation of the song, "Voljela sam, voljela" (I Loved, I Loved), in 1978, won the public over and resulted in sales of over a million copies; the public loved her and music critics praised her.

sentences: Hanka became recognized across the country of Yugoslavia and was offered to sing in guest spots and hold her own concerts.

sentences: She also won many awards and much recognition, including the "Oscar of Popularity", three "Golden Stars", as well as being named the female artist of the year.

sentences: At the same time she was preparing a full-length studio album, called Srebro i zlato (Silver and Gold"), named after the song.
section: == Biography == | === 1979–82: Voljela sam, voljela, Čežnja, and Sanjam ===

sentences: Along with Milić Vukašinović as the main songwriter, other recognized names from the world of Yugoslav folk, pop and rock music were present: Goran Bregović, Nikola Borota – Radovan, Bodo Kovačević, Mijat Božović, Blagoje Kosanin.
section: == Biography == | === 1979–82: Voljela sam, voljela, Čežnja, and Sanjam ===

sentences: Under Nikola Borota's direction, for the first time in Yugoslavian folk music history, electronic music instruments and pop music arrangements were used, songs had different rhythm section treatment than ever before and as a result Hanka's interpretations were different and original.
section: == Biography == | === 1979–82: Voljela sam, voljela, Čežnja, and Sanjam ===

sentences: With the song "Voljela sam, voljela" and the album Čežnja (1980), she merged folk and rock music.

sentences: Her work was not received well by music critics, composers and colleagues.
section: == Biography == | === 1979–82: Voljela sam, voljela, Čežnja, and Sanjam ===

sentences: They said her music undermined traditional folk music.

sentences: However, Hanka, along with her team, believed in herself and her success and was certain that the material, even if unusual and nontraditional, was something new and was of good quality.

sentences: That was confirmed later because Čežnja was overwhelmingly accepted by the public, broke many industry records, and sold over a million copies, and the songs in new folk-rock manner attracted listeners who had never before listened to her or folk music.
section: == Biography == | === 1979–82: Voljela sam, voljela, Čežnja, and Sanjam ===

sentences: With non-traditional business approach Hanka started attracting the media as well as the public: as the singer promoted the album Čežnja on Opatija festival of music, she also promoted it in Belgrade and had her first solo concert in Dom Sindikata, again musically produced by Nikola Borota – Radovan.

sentences: Lazar Ristovski was on synthesizers, Džemo Novaković on lead guitar, Sanin Karić was playing bass, two double drum kits were deployed while Ljubiša Pavković and Mico Radovanović were only two traditional instrumentalists present on stage, sharing the lead accordion roles.
section: == Biography == | === 1979–82: Voljela sam, voljela, Čežnja, and Sanjam ===

section: == Biography == | === 1979–82: Voljela sam, voljela, Čežnja, and Sanjam ===

sentences: Since then he has been sent to Mostar.

== Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: Torture allegations ===
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: In January 2013, Goran Golub, a Serb former captive in the Silos concentration camp accused Paldum of torturing him on 10 February 1993 during the Bosnian War.
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: Golub said that while he was a prisoner in the camp, Paldum and fellow Bosnian singer Dino Merlin were to perform for the soldiers of the Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina on Igman mountain, where Silos was located.
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: On that day, Golub alleges to have seen Paldum walking around the camp wearing an army outfit, when she saw him looking at her, he claims she approached him and yelled "What are you looking at?"
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: When he didn't reply, he then claims Paldum asked him, "Do you wanna fuck me?
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: Is that it?"
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: When he didn't reply again, he alleges that Paldum ordered him to sit down and spread his legs, then he claims that she stepped on his genitals with all her strength.
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: Golub further claims that that sexual torture is why he never married and that he thinks of the torture every time he urinates.
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: Paldum denied the allegations and further stated that she had never even been in Silos during the war.
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: She did state that the first time she left the city of Sarajevo during the siege and war was on 6 September 1993, not long after the Sarajevo Tunnel opened.
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: She went to the Igman mountain with several singers, one of which was Dino Merlin, to perform for the Bosnian soldiers.
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: When asked if she had seen or had any contact with Serb prisoners during the war, she said "No!
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: Never, never!"
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: After the concert, she and the other singers were brought back to the city of Sarajevo with a helicopter.
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: The allegations created a whirlwind of media attention in the former Yugoslav countries.
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: Serbian singer Jelena Karleuša offered her support to Paldum during a television appearance on Pink BH.
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: Paldum filed a lawsuit against Golub's lawyer Duško Tomić in March 2013 for false accusations of war crimes and torture.
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: That same month she was quoted as saying: "As for me, I cannot wait for an investigation to be launched into the allegations that the media highlighted and I wish to clear this stain off my name and prove that I am innocent.
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===

sentences: I cannot wait for all this to be over."
section: == Personal life == | === Torture allegations ===
